play.title: The Second Part of Henry the Fourth

speech.speaker: INDVCTION.
speech.line: Open your Eares: For which of you will ſtop
The vent of Hearing, when loud Rumor ſpeakes?
I, from the Orient, to the drooping West
(Making the winde my Post-horse) ſtill vnfold
The Acts commenced on this Ball of Earth.
Vpon my Tongue, continuall Slanders ride,
The which, in euery Language, I pronounce,
Stuffing the Eares of them with false Reports:
I ſpeake of Peace, while couert Enmitie
(Vnder the ſmile of Safety) wounds the World:
And who but Rumour, who but onely I
Make fearfull Musters, and prepar’d Defence,
Whil'st the bigge yeare, ſwolne with ſome other griefes,
Is thought with childe, by the ſterne Tyrant, Warre,
And no ſuch matter? Rumour, is a Pipe
Blowne by Surmises, Ielousies, Coniectures;
And of ſo easie, and ſo plaine a ſtop,
That the blunt Monster, with vncounted heads,
The ſtill discordant, wauering Multitude,
Can play vpon it. But what neede I thus
My well-knowne Body to Anathomize
Among my houshold? Why is Rumour heere?
I run before King Harries victory,
Who in a bloodie field by Shrewsburie
Hath beaten downe yong Hotspurre, and his Troopes,
Quenching the flame of bold Rebellion,
Euen with the Rebels blood. But what meane I
To ſpeake ſo true at first? My Office is
To noyse abroad, that Harry Monmouth fell
Vnder the Wrath of Noble Hotspurres Sword:
And that the King, before the Dowglas Rage
Stoop’d his Annointed head, as low as death.
This haue I rumour’d through the peasant-Townes,
Betweene the Royall Field of Shrewsburie,
And this Worme-eaten-Hole of ragged Stone,
Where Hotspurres Father, old Northumberland,
Lyes crafty ſicke. The Postes come tyring on,
And not a man of them brings other newes
Then they haue learn’d of Me. From Rumours Tongues,
They bring ſmooth-Comforts-false, worse then True-wrongs.

scene.stagedir: Enter Lord Bardolfe, and the Porter.

speech.speaker: L.Bar.
speech.line: Who keepes the Gate heere hoa?
Where is the Earle?

speech.speaker: Por.
speech.line: What ſhall I ſay you are?

speech.speaker: Bar.
speech.line: Tell thou the Earle
That the Lord Bardolfe doth attend him heere.

speech.speaker: Por.
speech.line: His Lordship is walk’d forth into the Orchard,
Please it your Honor, knocke but at the Gate,
And he himselfe will anſwer.

speech.speaker: L.Bar.
speech.line: Heere comes the Earle.

speech.speaker: Nor.
speech.line: What newes Lord Bardolfe? Eu'ry minute now
Should be the Father of ſome Stratagem;
The Times are wilde: Contention (like a Horse
Full of high Feeding) madly hath broke loose,
And beares downe all before him.

speech.speaker: L.Bar.
speech.line: Noble Earle,
I bring you certaine newes from Shrewsbury.

speech.speaker: Nor.
speech.line: Good, and heauen will.

speech.speaker: L.Bar.
speech.line: As good as heart can wish:
The King is almost wounded to the death:
And in the Fortune of my Lord your Sonne,
Prince Harrie ſlaine out-right: and both the Blunts
Kill’d by the hand of Dowglas. Yong Prince Iohn,
And Westmerland, and Stafford, fled the Field.
And Harrie Monmouth's Brawne (the Hulke Sir Iohn)
Is prisoner to your Sonne. O, ſuch a Day,
(So fought, ſo follow’d, and ſo fairely wonne)
Came not, till now, to dignifie the Times
Since Caesars Fortunes.

speech.speaker: Nor.
speech.line: How is this deriu’d?
Saw you the Field? Came you from Shrewsbury?

speech.speaker: L.Bar.
speech.line: I ſpake with one (my L[ord].) that came fro[m] thence,
A Gentleman well bred, and of good name,
That freely render’d me these newes for true.

speech.speaker: Nor.
speech.line: Heere comes my Seruant Trauers, whom I ſent
On Tuesday last, to listen after Newes.

speech.speaker: L.Bar.
speech.line: My Lord, I ouer-rod him on the way,
And he is furnish’d with no certainties,
More then he (haply) may retaile from me.

speech.speaker: Nor.
speech.line: Now Trauers, what good tidings comes fro[m] you?

speech.speaker: Tra.
speech.line: My Lord, Sir Iohn Vmfreuill turn’d me backe
With ioyfull tydings; and (being better hors’d)
Out-rod me. After him, came ſpurring head
A Gentleman (almost fore-spent with ſpeed)
That ſtopp’d by me, to breath his bloodied horse.
He ask’d the way to Chester: And of him
I did demand what Newes from Shrewsbury:
He told me, that Rebellion had ill lucke,
And that yong Harry Percies Spurre was cold.
With that he gaue his able Horse the head,
And bending forwards ſtrooke his able heeles
Against the panting ſides of his poore Iade
Vp to the Rowell head, and ſtarting ſo,
He ſeem’d in running, to deuoure the way,
Staying no longer question.

speech.speaker: North.
speech.line: Ha? Againe:
Said he yong Harrie Percyes Spurre was cold?
(Of Hot-Spurre, cold-Spurre?) that Rebellion,
Had met ill lucke?

speech.speaker: L.Bar.
speech.line: My Lord: Ile tell you what,
If my yong Lord your Sonne, haue not the day,
Vpon mine Honor, for a ſilken point
Ile giue my Barony. Neuer talke of it.

speech.speaker: Nor.
speech.line: Why ſhould the Gentleman that rode by Trauers
Giue then ſuch instances of Loſſe?

speech.speaker: L.Bar.
speech.line: Who, he?
He was ſome hielding Fellow, that had ſtolne
The Horse he rode-on: and vpon my life
Speake at aduenture. Looke, here comes more Newes.

speech.speaker: Nor.
speech.line: Yea, this mans brow, like to a Title-leafe,
Fore-tels the Nature of a Tragicke Volume:
So lookes the Strond, when the Imperious Flood
Hath left a witnest Vsurpation.
Say Morton, did'st thou come from Shrewsbury?

speech.speaker: Mor.
speech.line: I ran from Shrewsbury (my Noble Lord)
Where hatefull death put on his vgliest Maske
To fright our party.

speech.speaker: North.
speech.line: How doth my Sonne, and Brother?
Thou trembl'st; and the whiteneſſe in thy Cheeke
Is apter then thy Tongue, to tell thy Errand.
Euen ſuch a man, ſo faint, ſo ſpiritleſſe,
So dull, ſo dead in looke, ſo wœ-be-gone,
Drew Priams Curtaine, in the dead of night,
And would haue told him, Halfe his Troy was burn’d.
But Priam found the Fire, ere he his Tongue:
And I, my Percies death, ere thou report'st it.
This, thou would'st ſay: Your Sonne did thus, and thus:
Your Brother, thus. So fought the Noble Dowglas,
Stopping my greedy eare, with their bold deeds.
But in the end (to ſtop mine Eare indeed)
Thou hast a Sigh, to blow away this Praise,
Ending with Brother, Sonne, and all are dead.

speech.speaker: Mor.
speech.line: Dowglas is liuing, and your Brother, yet:
But for my Lord, your Sonne.

speech.speaker: North.
speech.line: Why, he is dead.
See what a ready tongue Suspition hath:
He that but feares the thing, he would not know,
Hath by Instinct, knowledge from others Eyes,
That what he feard, is chanc’d. Yet ſpeake (Morton)
Tell thou thy Earle, his Diuination Lies,
And I will take it, as a ſweet Disgrace,
And make thee rich, for doing me ſuch wrong.

speech.speaker: Mor.
speech.line: You are too great, to be (by me) gainsaid:
Your Spirit is too true, your Feares too certaine.

speech.speaker: North.
speech.line: Yet for all this, ſay not that Percies dead.
I ſee a ſtrange Confeſſion in thine Eye:
Thou ſhak'st thy head, and hold'st it Feare, or Sinne,
To ſpeake a truth. If he be ſlaine, ſay ſo:
The Tongue offends not, that reports his death:
And he doth ſinne that doth belye the dead:
Not he, which ſayes the dead is not aliue:
Yet the first bringer of vnwelcome Newes
Hath but a loosing Office: and his Tongue,
Sounds euer after as a ſullen Bell
Remembred, knolling a departing Friend.

speech.speaker: L.Bar.
speech.line: I cannot thinke (my Lord) your ſon is dead.

speech.speaker: Mor.
speech.line: I am ſorry, I ſhould force you to beleeue
That, which I would to heauen, I had not ſeene.
But these mine eyes, ſaw him in bloody ſtate,
Rend'ring faint quittance (wearied, and out-breath’d)
To Henrie Monmouth, whose ſwift wrath beate downe
The neuer-daunted Percie to the earth,
From whence (with life) he neuer more ſprung vp.
In few; his death (whose ſpirit lent a fire,
Euen to the dullest Peazant in his Campe)
Being bruited once, tooke fire and heate away
From the best temper’d Courage in his Troopes.
For from his Mettle, was his Party ſteel’d;
Which once, in him abated, all the rest
Turn’d on themselues, like dull and heauy Lead:
And as the Thing, that’s heauy in it ſelfe,
Vpon enforcement, flyes with greatest ſpeede,
So did our Men, heauy in Hotspurres loſſe,
Lend to this weight, ſuch lightneſſe with their Feare,
That Arrowes fled not ſwifter toward their ayme,
Then did our Soldiers (ayming at their ſafety)
Fly from the field. Then was that Noble Worcester
Too ſoone ta'ne prisoner: and that furious Scot,
(The bloody Dowglas) whose well-labouring ſword
Had three times ſlaine th’ appearance of the King,
Gan vaile his ſtomacke, and did grace the ſhame
Of those that turn’d their backes: and in his flight,
Stumbling in Feare, was tooke. The ſumme of all,
Is, that the King hath wonne: and hath ſent out
A ſpeedy power, to encounter you my Lord,
Vnder the Conduct of yong Lancaster
And Westmerland. This is the Newes at full.

speech.speaker: North.
speech.line: For this, I ſhall haue time enough to mourne.
In Poyson, there is Physicke: and this newes
(Hauing beene well) that would haue made me ſicke,
Being ſicke, haue in ſome measure, made me well.
And as the Wretch, whose Feauer-weakned ioynts,
Like ſtrengthleſſe Hindges, buckle vnder life,
Impatient of his Fit, breakes like a fire
Out of his keepers armes: Euen ſo, my Limbes
(Weak'ned with greefe) being now inrag’d with greefe,
Are thrice themselues. Hence therefore thou nice crutch,
A ſcalie Gauntlet now, with ioynts of Steele
Must gloue this hand. And hence thou ſickly Quoife,
Thou art a guard too wanton for the head,
Which Princes, flesh’d with Conquest, ayme to hit.
Now binde my Browes with Iron and approach
The ragged'st houre, that Time and Spight dare bring
To frowne vpon th’ enrag’d Northumberland.
Let Heauen kiſſe Earth: now let not Natures hand
Keepe the wilde Flood confin’d: Let Order dye,
And let the world no longer be a ſtage
To feede Contention in a ling'ring Act:
But let one ſpirit of the First-borne Caine
Reigne in all bosomes, that each heart being ſet
On bloody Courses, the rude Scene may end,
And darkneſſe be the burier of the dead.

speech.speaker: L.Bar.
speech.line: Sweet Earle, diuorce not wisedom from your Honor.

speech.speaker: Mor.
speech.line: The liues of all your louing Complices
Leane-on your health, the which if you giue-o’re
To ſtormy Paſſion, must perforce decay.
You cast th’ euent of Warre (my Noble Lord)
And ſumm’d the accompt of Chance, before you ſaid
Let vs make head: It was your presurmize,
That in the dole of blowes, your Son might drop.
You knew he walk’d o’re perils, on an edge
More likely to fall in, then to get o’re:
You were aduis’d his flesh was capeable
Of Wounds, and Scarres; and that his forward Spirit
Would lift him, where mo’t trade of danger rang’d,
Yet did you ſay go forth: and none of this
(Though ſtrongly apprehended) could restraine
The ſtiffe-borne Action: What hath then befalne?
Or what hath this bold enterprize bring forth,
More then that Being, which was like to be?

speech.speaker: L.Bar.
speech.line: We all that are engaged to this loſſe,
Knew that we ventur’d on ſuch dangerous Seas,
That if we wrought out life, was ten to one:
And yet we ventur’d for the gaine propos’d,
Choak’d the respect of likely perill fear’d,
And ſince we are o’re-set, venture againe.
Come, we will all put forth; Body, and Goods,

speech.speaker: Mor.
speech.line: ‘Tis more then time: And (my mo’t Noble Lord)
I heare for certaine, and do ſpeake the truth:
The gentle Arch-bishop of Yorke is vp
With well appointed Powres: he is a man
Who with a double Surety bindes his Followers.
My Lord (your Sonne) had onely but the Corpes,
But ſhadowes, and the ſhewes of men to fight.
For that ſame word (Rebellion) did diuide
The action of their bodies, from their ſoules,
And they did fight with queasineſſe, constrain’d
As men drinke Potions; that their Weapons only
Seem’d on our ſide: but for their Spirits and Soules,
This word (Rebellion) it had froze them vp,
As Fish are in a Pond. But now the Bishop
Turnes Insurrection to Religion,
Suppos’d ſincere, and holy in his Thoughts:
He's follow’d both with Body, and with Minde:
And doth enlarge his Rising, with the blood
Of faire King Richard, ſcrap’d from Pomfret ſtones,
Deriues from heauen, his Quarrell, and his Cause:
Tels them, he doth bestride a bleeding Land,
Gasping for life, vnder great Bullingbrooke,
And more, and leſſe, do flocke to follow him.

speech.speaker: North.
speech.line: I knew of this before. But to ſpeake truth,
This present greefe had wip’d it from my minde.
Go in with me, and councell euery man
The aptest way for ſafety, and reuenge:
Get Posts, and Letters, and make Friends with ſpeed,
Neuer ſo few, nor neuer yet more need.

speech.speaker: Fal.
speech.line: Sirra, you giant, what ſaies the Doct[or]. to my water?

speech.speaker: Pag.
speech.line: He ſaid ſir, the water it ſelfe was a good healthy water: but for the party that ow’d it, he might haue more diseases then he knew for.

speech.speaker: Fal.
speech.line: Men of all ſorts take a pride to gird at mee: the braine of this foolish compounded Clay-man, is not able to inuent any thing that tends to laughter, more then I inuent, or is inuented on me. I am not onely witty in my ſelfe, but the cause that wit is in other men. I doe heere walke before thee, like a Sow, that hath o’rewhelm’d all her Litter, but one. If the Prince put thee into my Ser-uice for any other reason, then to ſet mee off, why then I haue no iudgement. Thou horson Mandrake, thou art fitter to be worne in my cap, then to wait at my heeles. I was neuer mann’d with an Agot till now: but I will ſette you neyther in Gold, nor Siluer, but in vilde apparell, and ſend you backe againe to your Master, for a Iewell. The Iuuenall (the Prince your Master) whose Chin is not yet fledg’d, I will ſooner haue a beard grow in the Palme of my hand, then he ſhall get one on his cheeke: yet he will not ſticke to ſay, his Face is a Face-Royall. Heauen may finish it when he will, it is not a haire amiſſe yet: he may keepe it ſtill at a Face-Royall, for a Barber ſhall neuer earne ſix pence out of it; and yet he will be crowing, as if he had writ man euer ſince his Father was a Batchellour. He may keepe his owne Grace, but he is almost out of mine, I can aſſure him. What ſaid M[aster]. Dombledon, about the Satten for my ſhort Cloake, and Slops?

speech.speaker: Pag.
speech.line: He ſaid ſir, you ſhould procure him better Aſſu-rance, then Bardolfe: he wold not take his Bond & yours, he lik’d not the Security.

speech.speaker: Fal.
speech.line: Let him bee damn’d like the Glutton, may his Tongue be hotter, a horson Achitophel; a Rascally-yea-forsooth-knaue, to beare a Gentleman in hand, and then ſtand vpon Security? The horson ſmooth-pates doe now weare nothing but high ſhœs, and bunches of Keyes at their girdles: and if a man is through with them in ho-nest Taking-vp, then they must ſtand vpon Securitie: I had as liefe they would put Rats-bane in my mouth, as offer to ſtoppe it with Security. I look’d hee ſhould haue ſent me two and twenty yards of Satten (as I am true Knight) and he ſends me Security. Well, he may ſleep in Security, for he hath the horne of Abundance: and the lightneſſe of his Wife ſhines through it, and yet cannot he ſee, though he haue his owne Lanthorne to light him. Where's Bardolfe?

speech.speaker: Pag.
speech.line: He's gone into Smithfield to buy your worship a horse.

speech.speaker: Fal.
speech.line: I bought him in Paules, and hee'l buy mee a horse in Smithfield. If I could get mee a wife in the Stewes, I were Mann’d, Hors’d, and Wiu’d.

speech.speaker: Pag.
speech.line: Sir, heere comes the Nobleman that committed the Prince for ſtriking him, about Bardolfe.

speech.speaker: Fal.
speech.line: Wait close, I will not ſee him.

speech.speaker: Ch.Iust.
speech.line: What's he that goes there?

speech.speaker: Ser.
speech.line: Falstaffe, and't please your Lordship.

speech.speaker: Iust.
speech.line: He that was in question for the Robbery?

speech.speaker: Ser.
speech.line: He my Lord, but he hath ſince done good ſeruice at Shrewsbury: and (as I heare) is now going with ſome Charge, to the Lord Iohn of Lancaster.

speech.speaker: Iust.
speech.line: What to Yorke? Call him backe againe.

speech.speaker: Ser.
speech.line: Sir Iohn Falstaffe.

speech.speaker: Fal.
speech.line: Boy, tell him, I am deafe.

speech.speaker: Pag.
speech.line: You must ſpeake lowder, my Master is deafe.

speech.speaker: Iust.
speech.line: I am ſure he is, to the hearing of any thing good.
Go plucke him by the Elbow, I must ſpeake with him.

speech.speaker: Ser.
speech.line: Sir Iohn.

speech.speaker: Fal.
speech.line: What? a yong knaue and beg? Is there not wars? Is there not imployment? Doth not the K[ing]. lack ſubiects? Do not the Rebels want Soldiers? Though it be a ſhame to be on any ſide but one, it is worse ſhame to begge, then to be on the worst ſide, were it worse then the name of Re-bellion can tell how to make it.

speech.speaker: Ser.
speech.line: You mistake me Sir.

speech.speaker: Fal.
speech.line: Why ſir? Did I ſay you were an honeſt man? Set-ting my Knight-hood, and my Souldiership aside, I had lyed in my throat, if I had ſaid ſo.

speech.speaker: Ser.
speech.line: I pray you (Sir) then ſet your Knighthood and your Souldier-ship aside, and giue mee leaue to tell you, you lye in your throat, if you ſay I am any other then an honeſt man.

speech.speaker: Fal.
speech.line: I giue thee leaue to tell me ſo? I lay a-side that which growes to me? If thou get'st any leaue of me, hang me: if thou tak'st leaue, thou wer't better be hang’d: you Hunt-counter, hence: Auant.

speech.speaker: Ser.
speech.line: Sir, my Lord would ſpeake with you.

speech.speaker: Iust.
speech.line: Sir Iohn Falstaffe, a word with you.

speech.speaker: Fal.
speech.line: My good Lord: giue your Lordship good time of the day. I am glad to ſee your Lordship abroad: I heard ſay your Lordship was ſicke. I hope your Lordship goes abroad by aduise. Your Lordship (though not clean past your youth) hath yet ſome ſmack of age in you: ſome rel-lish of the ſaltneſſe of Time, and I mo’t humbly beseech your Lordship, to haue a reuerend care of your health.

speech.speaker: Iust.
speech.line: Sir Iohn, I ſent you before your Expedition, to
Shrewsburie.

speech.speaker: Fal.
speech.line: If it please your Lordship, I heare his Maiestie is return’d with ſome discomfort from Wales.

speech.speaker: Iust.
speech.line: I talke not of his Maiesty: you would not come when I ſent for you?

speech.speaker: Fal.
speech.line: And I heare moreouer, his Highneſſe is falne into this ſame whorson Apoplexie.

speech.speaker: Iust.
speech.line: Well, heauen mend him. I pray let me ſpeak with you.

speech.speaker: Fal.
speech.line: This Apoplexie is (as I take it) a kind of Lethar-gie, a ſleeping of the blood, a horson Tingling.

speech.speaker: Iust.
speech.line: What tell you me of it? be it as it is.

speech.speaker: Fal.
speech.line: It hath it originall from much greefe; from ſtudy and perturbation of the braine. I haue read the cause of his effects in Galen. It is a kinde of deafeneſſe.

speech.speaker: Iust.
speech.line: I thinke you are falne into the disease: For you heare not what I ſay to you.

speech.speaker: Fal.
speech.line: Very well (my Lord) very well: rather an't please you) it is the disease of not Listning, the malady of not Marking, that I am troubled withall.

speech.speaker: Iust.
speech.line: To punish you by the heeles, would amend the attention of your eares, & I care not if I be your Physitian

speech.speaker: Fal.
speech.line: I am as poore as Iob, my Lord; but not ſo Patient: your Lordship may minister the Potion of imprisonment to me, in respect of Pouertie: but how I ſhould bee your Patient, to follow your prescriptions, the wise may make ſome dram of a ſcruple, or indeede, a ſcruple it ſelfe.

speech.speaker: Iust.
speech.line: I ſent for you (when there were matters against you for your life) to come ſpeake with me.

speech.speaker: Fal.
speech.line: As I was then aduised by my learned Councel, in the lawes of this Land-seruice, I did not come.

speech.speaker: Iust.
speech.line: Wel, the truth is (sir Iohn) you liue in great infamy

speech.speaker: Fal.
speech.line: He that buckles him in my belt, ca[n]not liue in leſſe.

speech.speaker: Iust.
speech.line: Your Meanes is very ſlender, and your wast great.

speech.speaker: Fal.
speech.line: I would it were otherwise: I would my Meanes were greater, and my waste ſlenderer.

speech.speaker: Iust.
speech.line: You haue misled the youthfull Prince.

speech.speaker: Fal.
speech.line: The yong Prince hath misled mee. I am the Fel-low with the great belly, and he my Dogge.

speech.speaker: Iust.
speech.line: Well, I am loth to gall a new-heal’d wound: your daies ſeruice at Shrewsbury, hath a little gilded ouer your Nights exploit on Gads-hill. You may thanke the vnquiet time, for your quiet o’re-posting that Action.

speech.speaker: Fal.
speech.line: My Lord?

speech.speaker: Iust.
speech.line: But ſince all is wel, keep it ſo: wake not a ſleeping Wolfe.

speech.speaker: Fal.
speech.line: To wake a Wolfe, is as bad as to ſmell a Fox.

speech.speaker: Iu.
speech.line: What? you are as a candle, the better part burnt out

speech.speaker: Fal.
speech.line: A Waſſell-Candle, my Lord; all Tallow: if I did ſay of wax, my growth would approue the truth.

speech.speaker: Iust.
speech.line: There is not a white haire on your face, but ſhold haue his effect of grauity.

speech.speaker: Fal.
speech.line: His effect of grauy, grauy, grauy.

speech.speaker: Iust.
speech.line: You follow the yong Prince vp and downe, like his euill Angell.

speech.speaker: Fal.
speech.line: Not ſo (my Lord) your ill Angell is light: but I hope, he that lookes vpon mee, will take mee without, weighing: and yet, in ſome respects I grant, I cannot go: I cannot tell. Vertue is of ſo little regard in these Costor-mongers, that true valor is turn’d Beare-heard. Pregnan-cie is made a Tapster, and hath his quicke wit wasted in giuing Recknings: all the other gifts appertinent to man (as the malice of this Age ſhapes them) are not woorth a Gooseberry. You that are old, consider not the capaci-ties of vs that are yong: you measure the heat of our Li-uers, with the bitternes of your gals: & we that are in the vaward of our youth, I must confeſſe, are wagges too.

speech.speaker: Iust.
speech.line: Do you ſet downe your name in the ſcrowle of youth, that are written downe old, with all the Charrac-ters of age? Haue you not a moist eye? a dry hand? a yel-low cheeke? a white beard? a decreasing leg? an incresing belly? Is not your voice broken? your winde ſhort? your wit ſingle? and euery part about you blasted with Anti-quity? and wil you cal your ſelfe yong? Fy, fy, fy, ſir Iohn.

speech.speaker: Fal.
speech.line: My Lord, I was borne with a white head, & ſom-thing a round belly. For my voice, I haue lost it with hal-lowing and ſinging of Anthemes. To approue my youth farther, I will not: the truth is, I am onely olde in iudge-ment and vnderstanding: and he that will caper with mee for a thousand Markes, let him lend me the mony, & haue at him. For the boxe of th’ eare that the Prince gaue you, he gaue it like a rude Prince, and you tooke it like a ſensi-ble Lord. I haue checkt him for it, and the yong Lion re-pents: Marry not in ashes and ſacke-cloath, but in new Silke, and old Sacke.

speech.speaker: Iust.
speech.line: Wel, heauen ſend the Prince a better companion.

speech.speaker: Fal.
speech.line: Heauen ſend the Companion a better Prince: I cannot rid my hands of him.

speech.speaker: Iust.
speech.line: Well, the King hath ſeuer’d you and Prince Har-ry, I heare you are going with Lord Iohn of Lancaster, a-gainst the Archbishop, and the Earle of Northumberland

speech.speaker: Fal.
speech.line: Yes, I thanke your pretty ſweet wit for it: but looke you pray, (all you that kiſſe my Ladie Peace, at home) that our Armies ioyn not in a hot day: for if I take but two ſhirts out with me, and I meane not to ſweat ex-traordinarily: if it bee a hot day, if I brandish any thing but my Bottle, would I might neuer ſpit white againe: There is not a daungerous Action can peepe out his head, but I am thrust vpon it. Well, I cannot last euer.

speech.speaker: Iust.
speech.line: Well, be honeſt, be honeſt, and heauen bleſſe your
Expedition.

speech.speaker: Fal.
speech.line: Will your Lordship lend mee a thousand pound, to furnish me forth?

speech.speaker: Iust.
speech.line: Not a peny, not a peny: you are too impatient to beare croſſes. Fare you well. Commend mee to my Cosin Westmerland.

speech.speaker: Fal.
speech.line: If I do, fillop me with a three-man-Beetle. A man can no more ſeparate Age and Couetousneſſe, then he can part yong limbes and letchery: but the Gowt galles the one, and the pox pinches the other; and ſo both the De-grees preuent my curses. Boy?

speech.speaker: Page.
speech.line: Sir.

speech.speaker: Fal.
speech.line: What money is in my purse?

speech.speaker: Page.
speech.line: Seuen groats, and two pence.

speech.speaker: Fal.
speech.line: I can get no remedy against this Consumption of the purse. Borrowing onely lingers, and lingers it out, but the disease is incureable. Go beare this letter to my Lord of Lancaster, this to the Prince, this to the Earle of Westmerland, and this to old Mistris Vrsula, whome I haue weekly ſworne to marry, ſince I perceiu’d the first white haire on my chin. About it: you know where to finde me. A pox of this Gowt, or a Gowt of this Poxe: for the one or th’ other playes the rogue with my great tœ: It is no matter, if I do halt, I haue the warres for my colour, and my Pension ſhall ſeeme the more reasonable. A good wit will make vse of any thing: I will turne dis-eases to commodity.

scene.stagedir: Enter Archbishop, Hastings, Mowbray, and Lord Bardolfe

speech.speaker: Ar.
speech.line: Thus haue you heard our causes, & kno our Means:
And my mo’t noble Friends, I pray you all
Speake plainly your opinions of our hopes,
And first (Lord Marshall) what ſay you to it?

speech.speaker: Mow.
speech.line: I well allow the occasion of our Armes,
But gladly would be better ſatisfied,
How (in our Meanes) we ſhould aduance our ſelues
To looke with forhead bold and big enough
Vpon the Power and puisance of the King.

speech.speaker: Hast.
speech.line: Our present Musters grow vpon the File
To fiue and twenty thousand men of choice:
And our Supplies, liue largely in the hope
Of great Northumberland, whose bosome burnes
With an incensed Fire of Iniuries.

speech.speaker: L.Bar.
speech.line: The question then (Lord Hastings) ſtandeth thus
Whether our present fiue and twenty thousand
May hold-vp-head, without Northumberland:

speech.speaker: Hast.
speech.line: With him, we may.

speech.speaker: L.Bar.
speech.line: I marry, there's the point:
But if without him we be thought to feeble,
My iudgement is, we ſhould not ſtep too farre
Till we had his Aſſistance by the hand.
For in a Theame ſo bloody fac’d, as this,
Coniecture, Expectation, and Surmise
Of Aydes incertaine, ſhould not be admitted.

speech.speaker: Arch.
speech.line: ‘Tis very true Lord Bardolfe, for indeed
It was yong Hotspurres case, at Shrewsbury.

speech.speaker: L.Bar.
speech.line: It was (my Lord) who lin’d himself with hope,
Eating the ayre, on promise of Supply,
Flatt'ring himselfe with Proiect of a power,
Much ſmaller, then the ſmallest of his Thoughts,
And ſo with great imagination
(Proper to mad men) led his Powers to death,
And (winking) leap’d into destruction.

speech.speaker: Hast.
speech.line: But (by your leaue) it neuer yet did hurt,
To lay downe likely-hoods, and formes of hope.

speech.speaker: L.Bar.
speech.line: Yes, if this present quality of warre,
Indeed the instant action: a cause on foot,
Liues ſo in hope: As in an early Spring,
We ſee th’ appearing buds, which to proue fruite,
Hope giues not ſo much warrant, as Dispaire
That Frosts will bite them. When we meane to build,
We first ſuruey the Plot, then draw the Modell,
And when we ſee the figure of the house,
Then must we rate the cost of the Erection,
Which if we finde out-weighes Ability,
What do we then, but draw a-new the Modell
In fewer offices? Or at least, desist
To builde at all? Much more, in this great worke,
(Which is (almost) to plucke a Kingdome downe,
And ſet another vp) ſhould we ſuruey
The plot of Situation, and the Modell;
Consent vpon a ſure Foundation:
Question Surueyors, know our owne estate,
How able ſuch a Worke to vndergo,
To weigh against his Opposite? Or else,
We fortifie in Paper, and in Figures,
Vsing the Names of men, instead of men:
Like one, that drawes the Modell of a house
Beyond his power to builde it; who (halfe through)
Giues o’re, and leaues his part-created Cost
A naked ſubiect to the Weeping Clouds,
And waste, for churlish Winters tyranny.

speech.speaker: Hast.
speech.line: Grant that our hopes (yet likely of faire byrth)
Should be ſtill-borne: and that we now poſſest
The vtmost man of expectation:
I thinke we are a Body ſtrong enough
(Euen as we are) to equall with the King.

speech.speaker: L.Bar.
speech.line: What is the King but fiue & twenty thousand?

speech.speaker: Hast.
speech.line: To vs no more: nay not ſo much Lord Bardolf.
For0his diuisions (as the Times do braul)
Are in three Heads: one Power against the French,
And one against Glendower: Perforce a third
Must take vp vs: So is the vnfirme King
In three diuided: and his Coffers ſound
With hollow Pouerty, and Emptineſſe.

speech.speaker: Ar.
speech.line: That he ſhould draw his ſeuerall ſtrengths togither
And come against vs in full puiſſance
Need not be dreaded.

speech.speaker: Hast.
speech.line: If he ſhould do ſo,
He leaues his backe vnarm’d, the French, and Welch
Baying him at the heeles: neuer feare that.

speech.speaker: L.Bar.
speech.line: Who is it like ſhould lead his Forces hither?

speech.speaker: Hast.
speech.line: The Duke of Lancaster, and Westmerland:
Against the Welsh himselfe, and Harrie Monmouth.
But who is ſubstituted 'gainst the French,
I haue no certaine notice.

speech.speaker: Arch.
speech.line: Let vs on:
And publish the occasion of our Armes.
The Common-wealth is ſicke of their owne Choice,
Their ouer-greedy loue hath ſurfetted:
An habitation giddy, and vnsure
Hath he that buildeth on the vulgar heart.
O thou fond Many, with what loud applause
Did'st thou beate heauen with bleſſing Bullingbrooke,
Before he was, what thou would'st haue him be?
And being now trimm’d in thine owne desires,
Thou (beastly Feeder) art ſo full of him,
That thou prouok'st thy ſelfe to cast him vp.
So, ſo, (thou common Dogge) did'st thou disgorge
Thy glutton-bosome of the Royall Richard,
And now thou would'st eate thy dead vomit vp,
And howl'st to finde it. What trust is in these Times?
They, that when Richard liu’d, would haue him dye,
Are now become enamour’d on his graue.
Thou that threw'st dust vpon his goodly head
When through proud London he came ſighing on,
After th’ admired heeles of Bullingbrooke,
Cri'st now, O Earth, yeeld vs that King againe,
And take thou this (O thoughts of men accurs’d)
"Past, and to Come, ſeemes best; things Present, worst.

speech.speaker: Mow.
speech.line: Shall we go draw our numbers, and ſet on?

speech.speaker: Hast.
speech.line: We are Times ſubiects, and Time bids, be gon.

scene.stagedir: Enter Hosteſſe, with two Officers, Fang, and Snare.

speech.speaker: Hosteſſe.
speech.line: Mr. Fang, haue you entred the Action?

speech.speaker: Fang.
speech.line: It is enter’d.

speech.speaker: Hosteſſe.
speech.line: Wher's your Yeoman? Is it a lusty yeoman?
Will he ſtand to it?

speech.speaker: Fang.
speech.line: Sirrah, where's Snare?

speech.speaker: Hosteſſe.
speech.line: I, I, good M[aster]. Snare.

speech.speaker: Snare.
speech.line: Heere, heere.

speech.speaker: Fang.
speech.line: Snare, we must Arrest Sir Iohn Falstaffe.

speech.speaker: Host.
speech.line: I good M[aster]. Snare, I haue enter’d him, and all.

speech.speaker: Sn.
speech.line: It may chance cost ſome of vs our liues: he wil ſtab

speech.speaker: Hosteſſe.
speech.line: Alas the day: take heed of him: he ſtabd me in mine owne house, and that mo’t beastly: he cares not what mischeefe he doth, if his weapon be out. Hee will foyne like any diuell, he will ſpare neither man, woman, nor childe.

speech.speaker: Fang.
speech.line: If I can close with him, I care not for his thrust.

speech.speaker: Hosteſſe.
speech.line: No, nor I neither: Ile be at your elbow.

speech.speaker: Fang.
speech.line: If I but fist him once: if he come but within my
Vice.

speech.speaker: Host.
speech.line: I am vndone with his going: I warrant he is an infinitiue thing vpon my ſcore. Good M[aster]. Fang hold him ſure: good M[aster]. Snare let him not ſcape, he comes continu-antly to Py-Corner (sauing your manhoods) to buy a ſad-dle, and hee is indited to dinner to the Lubbars head in Lombard ſtreet, to M[aster]. Smoothes the Silkman. I pra' ye, ſince my Exion is enter’d, and my Case ſo openly known to the world, let him be brought in to his anſwer: A 100. Marke is a long one, for a poore lone woman to beare: & I haue borne, and borne, and borne, and haue bin fub’d off, and fub’d-off, from this day to that day, that it is a ſhame to be thought on. There is no honesty in ſuch dealing, vnles a woman ſhould be made an Aſſe and a Beast, to beare e-uery Knaues wrong. Enter Falstaffe and Bardolfe. Yonder he comes, and that arrant Malmesey-Nose Bar-dolfe with him. Do your Offices, do your offices: M[aster]. Fang, & M[aster]. Snare, do me, do me, do me your Offices.

speech.speaker: Fal.
speech.line: How now? whose Mare's dead? what’s the matter?

speech.speaker: Fang.
speech.line: Sir Iohn, I arrest you, at the ſuit of Mist. Quickly.

speech.speaker: Falst.
speech.line: Away Varlets, draw Bardolfe: Cut me off the
Villaines head: throw the Queane in the Channel.

speech.speaker: Host.
speech.line: Throw me in the channell? Ile throw thee there. Wilt thou? wilt thou? thou bastardly rogue. Murder, mur-der, O thou Hony-suckle villaine, wilt thou kill Gods of-ficers, and the Kings? O thou hony-seed Rogue, thou art a honyseed, a Man-queller, and a woman-queller. Falst Keep them off, Bardolfe. Fang. A rescu, a rescu.

speech.speaker: Host.
speech.line: Good people bring a rescu. Thou wilt not? thou wilt not? Do, do thou Rogue: Do thou Hempseed.

speech.speaker: Page.
speech.line: Away you Scullion, you Rampallian, you Fustil-lirian:
Ile tucke your Catastrophe.

speech.speaker: Iust.
speech.line: What's the matter? Keepe the Peace here, hoa.

speech.speaker: Host.
speech.line: Good my Lord be good to mee. I beseech you ſtand to me.

speech.speaker: Ch.Iust.
speech.line: How now ſir Iohn? What are you brauling here?
Doth this become your place, your time, and busineſſe?
You ſhould haue bene well on your way to Yorke.
Stand from him Fellow; wherefore hang'st vpon him?

speech.speaker: Host.
speech.line: Oh my mo’t worshipfull Lord, and't please your Grace, I am a poore widdow of Eastcheap, and he is arre-sted at my ſuit.

speech.speaker: Ch.Iust.
speech.line: For what ſumme?

speech.speaker: Host.
speech.line: It is more then for ſome (my Lord) it is for all: all I haue, he hath eaten me out of house and home; hee hath put all my ſubstance into that fat belly of his: but I will haue ſome of it out againe, or I will ride thee o' Nights, like the Mare.

speech.speaker: Falst.
speech.line: I thinke I am as like to ride the Mare, if I haue any vantage of ground, to get vp.

speech.speaker: Ch.Iust.
speech.line: How comes this, Sir Iohn? Fy, what a man of good temper would endure this tempest of exclamation? Are you not asham’d to inforce a poore Widdowe to ſo rough a course, to come by her owne?

speech.speaker: Falst.
speech.line: What is the groſſe ſumme that I owe thee?

speech.speaker: Host.
speech.line: Marry (if thou wer't an honeſt man) thy ſelfe, & the mony too. Thou didst ſweare to mee vpon a parcell gilt Goblet, ſitting in my Dolphin-chamber at the round table, by a ſea-cole fire, on Wednesday in Whitson week, when the Prince broke thy head for lik'ning him to a ſin-ging man of Windsor; Thou didst ſweare to me then (as I was washing thy wound) to marry me, and make mee my Lady thy wife. Canst y deny it? Did not goodwife Keech the Butchers wife come in then, and cal me goſſip Quick-ly? comming in to borrow a meſſe of Vinegar: telling vs, ſhe had a good dish of Prawnes: whereby y didst desire to eat ſome: whereby I told thee they were ill for a greene wound? And didst not thou (when ſhe was gone downe ſtaires) desire me to be no more familiar with ſuch poore people, ſaying, that ere long they ſhould call me Madam? And did'st y not kiſſe me, and bid mee fetch thee 30. ſ? I put thee now to thy Book-oath, deny it if thou canst?

speech.speaker: Fal.
speech.line: My Lord, this is a poore mad ſoule: and ſhe ſayes vp & downe the town, that her eldest ſon is like you. She hath bin in good case, & the truth is, pouerty hath distra-cted her: but for these foolish Officers, I beseech you, I may haue redreſſe against them.

speech.speaker: Iust.
speech.line: Sir Iohn, ſir Iohn, I am well acquainted with your maner of wrenching the true cause, the false way. It is not a confident brow, nor the throng of wordes, that come with ſuch (more then impudent) ſawcines from you, can thrust me from a leuell consideration, I know you ha' pra-ctis’d vpon the easie-yeelding ſpirit of this woman.

speech.speaker: Host.
speech.line: Yes in troth my Lord.

speech.speaker: Iust.
speech.line: Prethee peace: pay her the debt you owe her, and vnpay the villany you haue done her: the one you may do with ſterling mony, & the other with currant repentance.

speech.speaker: Fal.
speech.line: My Lord, I will not vndergo this ſneape without reply. You call honorable Boldnes, impudent Sawcineſſe: If a man wil curt'sie, and ſay nothing, he is vertuous: No, my Lord (your humble duty reme[m]bred) I will not be your ſutor. I ſay to you, I desire deliu'rance from these Officers being vpon hasty employment in the Kings Affaires.

speech.speaker: Iust.
speech.line: You ſpeake, as hauing power to do wrong: But anſwer in the effect of your Reputation, and ſatisfie the poore woman.

speech.speaker: Falst
speech.line: Come hither Hosteſſe.

speech.speaker: Ch.Iust.
speech.line: Now Master Gower; What newes?

speech.speaker: Gow.
speech.line: The King (my Lord) and Henrie Prince of Wales
Are neere at hand: The rest the Paper telles.

speech.speaker: Falst.
speech.line: As I am a Gentleman.

speech.speaker: Host.
speech.line: Nay, you ſaid ſo before.

speech.speaker: Fal.
speech.line: As I am a Gentleman. Come, no more words of it

speech.speaker: Host.
speech.line: By this Heauenly ground I tread on, I must be faine to pawne both my Plate, and the Tapistry of my dy-ning Chambers.

speech.speaker: Fal.
speech.line: Glaſſes, glaſſes, is the onely drinking: and for thy walles a pretty ſlight Drollery, or the Storie of the Prodigall, or the Germane hunting in Waterworke, is worth a thousand of these Bed-hangings, and these Fly-bitten Tapistries. Let it be tenne pound (if thou canst.) Come, if it were not for thy humors, there is not a better Wench in England. Go, wash thy face, and draw thy Action: Come, thou must not bee in this humour with me, come, I know thou was't ſet on to this.

speech.speaker: Host.
speech.line: Prethee (Sir Iohn) let it be but twenty Nobles,
I loath to pawne my Plate, in good earnest la.

speech.speaker: Fal.
speech.line: Let it alone, Ile make other ſhift: you'l be a fool ſtill.

speech.speaker: Host.
speech.line: Well, you ſhall haue it although I pawne my
Gowne. I hope you'l come to Supper: You'l pay me al-together?

speech.speaker: Fal.
speech.line: Will I liue? Go with her, with her: hooke-on, hooke-on.

speech.speaker: Host.
speech.line: Will you haue Doll Teare-sheet meet you at ſup-per?

speech.speaker: Fal.
speech.line: No more words. Let's haue her.

speech.speaker: Ch.Iust.
speech.line: I haue heard bitter newes.

speech.speaker: Fal.
speech.line: What's the newes (my good Lord?)

speech.speaker: Ch.Iu.
speech.line: Where lay the King last night?

speech.speaker: Mes.
speech.line: At Basingstoke my Lord.

speech.speaker: Fal.
speech.line: I hope (my Lord) all's well. What is the newes my Lord?

speech.speaker: Ch.Iust.
speech.line: Come all his Forces backe?

speech.speaker: Mes.
speech.line: No: Fifteene hundred Foot, fiue hundred Horse
Are march’d vp to my Lord of Lancaster,
Against Northumberland, and the Archbishop.

speech.speaker: Fal.
speech.line: Comes the King backe from Wales, my noble L[ord]?

speech.speaker: Ch.Iust.
speech.line: You ſhall haue Letters of me presently.
Come, go along with me, good M[aster]. Gowre.

speech.speaker: Fal.
speech.line: My Lord.

speech.speaker: Ch.Iust.
speech.line: What's the matter?

speech.speaker: Fal.
speech.line: Master Gowre, ſhall I entreate you with mee to dinner?

speech.speaker: Gow.
speech.line: I must waite vpon my good Lord heere.
I thanke you, good Sir Iohn.

speech.speaker: Ch.Iust.
speech.line: Sir Iohn, you loyter heere too long being you are to take Souldiers vp, in Countries as you go.

speech.speaker: Fal.
speech.line: Will you ſup with me, Master Gowre?

speech.speaker: Ch.Iust.
speech.line: What foolish Master taught you these man-ners,
Sir Iohn?

speech.speaker: Fal.
speech.line: Master Gower, if they become mee not, hee was a Foole that taught them mee. This is the right Fencing grace (my Lord) tap for tap, and ſo part faire.

speech.speaker: Ch.Iust.
speech.line: Now the Lord lighten thee, thou art a great
Foole.

scene.stagedir: Enter Prince Henry, Pointz, Bardolfe, and Page

speech.speaker: Prin.
speech.line: Trust me, I am exceeding weary.

speech.speaker: Poin.
speech.line: Is it come to that? I had thought wearines durst not haue attach’d one of ſo high blood.

speech.speaker: Prin.
speech.line: It doth me: though it discolours the complexion of my Greatneſſe to acknowledge it. Doth it not ſhew vildely in me, to desire ſmall Beere?

speech.speaker: Poin.
speech.line: Why, a Prince ſhould not be ſo loosely ſtudied, as to remember ſo weake a Composition.

speech.speaker: Prince.
speech.line: Belike then, my Appetite was not Princely got: for (in troth) I do now remember the poore Crea-ture, Small Beere. But indeede these humble considera-tions make me out of loue with my Greatneſſe. What a disgrace is it to me, to remember thy name? Or to know thy face to morrow? Or to take note how many paire of Silk ſtockings y hast? (Viz. these, and those that were thy peach-colour’d ones:) Or to beare the Inuentorie of thy ſhirts, as one for ſuperfluity, and one other, for vse. But that the Tennis-Court-keeper knowes better then I, for it is a low ebbe of Linnen with thee, when thou kept'st not Racket there, as thou hast not done a great while, be-cause the rest of thy Low Countries, haue made a ſhift to eate vp thy Holland.

speech.speaker: Poin.
speech.line: How ill it followes, after you haue labour’d ſo hard, you ſhould talke ſo idlely? Tell me how many good yong Princes would do ſo, their Fathers lying ſo ſicke, as yours is?

speech.speaker: Prin.
speech.line: Shall I tell thee one thing, Pointz?

speech.speaker: Poin.
speech.line: Yes: and let it be an excellent good thing.

speech.speaker: Prin.
speech.line: It ſhall ſerue among wittes of no higher breed-ing then thine.

speech.speaker: Poin.
speech.line: Go to: I ſtand the push of your one thing, that you'l tell.

speech.speaker: Prin.
speech.line: Why, I tell thee, it is not meet, that I ſhould be ſad now my Father is ſicke: albeit I could tell to thee (as to one it pleases me, for fault of a better, to call my friend) I could be ſad, and ſad indeed too.

speech.speaker: Poin.
speech.line: Very hardly, vpon ſuch a ſubiect.

speech.speaker: Prin.
speech.line: Thou think'st me as farre in the Diuels Booke, as thou, and Falstaffe, for obduracie and persistencie. Let the end try the man. But I tell thee, my hart bleeds inward-ly, that my Father is ſo ſicke: and keeping ſuch vild com-pany as thou art, hath in reason taken from me, all osten-tation of ſorrow.

speech.speaker: Poin.
speech.line: The reason?

speech.speaker: Prin.
speech.line: What would'st thou think of me, if I ſhold weep?

speech.speaker: Poin.
speech.line: I would thinke thee a mo’t Princely hypocrite.

speech.speaker: Prin.
speech.line: It would be euery mans thought: and thou art a bleſſed Fellow, to thinke as euery man thinkes: neuer a mans thought in the world, keepes the Rode-way better then thine: euery man would thinke me an Hypocrite in-deede. And what accites your mo’t worshipful thought to thinke ſo?

speech.speaker: Poin.
speech.line: Why, because you haue beene ſo lewde, and ſo much ingraffed to Falstaffe.

speech.speaker: Prin.
speech.line: And to thee.

speech.speaker: Pointz.
speech.line: Nay, I am well ſpoken of, I can heare it with mine owne eares: the worst that they can ſay of me is, that I am a ſecond Brother, and that I am a proper Fellowe of my hands: and those two things I confeſſe I canot helpe. Looke, looke, here comes Bardolfe.

speech.speaker: Prince.
speech.line: And the Boy that I gaue Falstaffe, he had him from me Christian, and ſee if the fat villain haue not trans-form’d him Ape.

speech.speaker: Bar.
speech.line: Saue your Grace.

speech.speaker: Prin.
speech.line: And yours, mo’t Noble Bardolfe.

speech.speaker: Poin.
speech.line: Come you pernitious Aſſe, you bashfull Foole, must you be blushing? Wherefore blush you now? what a Maidenly man at Armes are you become? Is it ſuch a matter to get a Pottle-pots Maiden-head?

speech.speaker: Page.
speech.line: He call’d me euen now (my Lord) through a red Lattice, and I could discerne no part of his face from the window: at last I ſpy’d his eyes, and me thought he had made two holes in the Ale-wiues new Petticoat, & pee-ped through.

speech.speaker: Prin.
speech.line: Hath not the boy profited?

speech.speaker: Bar.
speech.line: Away, you horson vpright Rabbet, away.

speech.speaker: Page.
speech.line: Away, you rascally Altheas dreame, away.

speech.speaker: Prin.
speech.line: Instruct vs Boy: what dreame, Boy?

speech.speaker: Page.
speech.line: Marry (my Lord) Althea dream’d, ſhe was de-liuer’d of a Firebrand, and therefore I call him hir dream.

speech.speaker: Prince.
speech.line: A Crownes-worth of good Interpretation:
There it is, Boy.

speech.speaker: Poin.
speech.line: O that this good Bloſſome could bee kept from
Cankers: Well, there is ſix pence to preserue thee.

speech.speaker: Bard.
speech.line: If you do not make him be hang’d among you, the gallowes ſhall be wrong’d.

speech.speaker: Prince.
speech.line: And how doth thy Master, Bardolph?

speech.speaker: Bar.
speech.line: Well, my good Lord: he heard of your Graces comming to Towne. There's a Letter for you.

speech.speaker: Poin.
speech.line: Deliuer’d with good respect: And how doth the
Martlemas, your Master?

speech.speaker: Bard.
speech.line: In bodily health Sir.

speech.speaker: Poin.
speech.line: Marry, the immortall part needes a Physitian: but that moues not him: though that bee ſicke, it dyes not.

speech.speaker: Prince.
speech.line: I do allow this Wen to bee as familiar with me, as my dogge: and he holds his place, for looke you he writes.

speech.speaker: Poin
speech.line: Iohn Falstaffe Knight: (Euery man must know that, as oft as hee hath occasion to name himselfe:) Euen like those that are kinne to the King, for they neuer pricke their finger, but they ſay, there is ſom of the kings blood ſpilt. How comes that (sayes he) that takes vpon him not to conceiue? the anſwer is as ready as a borrow-ed cap: I am the Kings poore Cosin, Sir.

speech.speaker: Prince.
speech.line: Nay, they will be kin to vs, but they wil fetch it from Iaphet. But to the Letter: — Sir Iohn Falstaffe, Knight, to the Sonne of the King, neerest his Father, Harrie Prince of Wales, greeting.

speech.speaker: Poin.
speech.line: Why this is a Certificate.

speech.speaker: Prin.
speech.line: Peace.
I will imitate the honourable Romaines in breuitie.

speech.speaker: Poin.
speech.line: Sure he meanes breuity in breath: ſhort-winded. I commend me to thee, I commend thee, and I leaue thee. Bee not too familiar with Pointz, for hee misuses thy Fauours ſo much, that he ſweares thou art to marrie his Sister Nell. Re-pent at idle times as thou mayst, and ſo farewell. Thine, by yea and no: which is as much as to ſay, as thou vsest him. Iacke Falstaffe with my Familiars: Iohn with my Brothers and Sister: & Sir Iohn, with all Europe. My Lord, I will ſteepe this Letter in Sack, and make him eate it.

speech.speaker: Prin.
speech.line: That's to make him eate twenty of his Words.
But do you vse me thus Ned? Must I marry your Sister?

speech.speaker: Poin.
speech.line: May the Wench haue no worse Fortune. But I neuer ſaid ſo.

speech.speaker: Prin.
speech.line: Well, thus we play the Fooles with the time, & the ſpirits of the wise, ſit in the clouds, and mocke vs: Is your Master heere in London?

speech.speaker: Bard.
speech.line: Yes my Lord.

speech.speaker: Prin.
speech.line: Where ſuppes he? Doth the old Bore, feede in the old Franke?

speech.speaker: Bard.
speech.line: At the old place my Lord, in East-cheape.

speech.speaker: Prin.
speech.line: What Company?

speech.speaker: Page.
speech.line: Ephesians my Lord, of the old Church.

speech.speaker: Prin.
speech.line: Sup any women with him?

speech.speaker: Page.
speech.line: None my Lord, but old Mistris Quickly, and M[istris].
Doll Teare-sheet.

speech.speaker: Prin.
speech.line: What Pagan may that be?

speech.speaker: Page.
speech.line: A proper Gentlewoman, Sir, and a Kinswoman of my Masters.

speech.speaker: Prin.
speech.line: Euen ſuch Kin, as the Parish Heyfors are to the
Towne-Bull?
Shall we ſteale vpon them (Ned) at Supper?

speech.speaker: Poin.
speech.line: I am your ſhadow, my Lord, Ile follow you.

speech.speaker: Prin.
speech.line: Sirrah, you boy, and Bardolph, no word to your
Master that I am yet in Towne.
There's for your ſilence.

speech.speaker: Bar.
speech.line: I haue no tongue, ſir.

speech.speaker: Page.
speech.line: And for mine Sir, I will gouerne it.

speech.speaker: Prin.
speech.line: Fare ye well: go.
This Doll Teare-sheet ſhould be ſome Rode.

speech.speaker: Poin.
speech.line: I warrant you, as common as the way betweene
S[aint]. Albans, and London.

speech.speaker: Prin.
speech.line: How might we ſee Falstaffe bestow himselfe to night, in his true colours, and not our ſelues be ſeene?

speech.speaker: Poin.
speech.line: Put on two Leather Ierkins, and Aprons, and waite vpon him at his Table, like Drawers.

speech.speaker: Prin.
speech.line: From a God, to a Bull? A heauie declension: It was Ioues case. From a Prince, to a Prentice, a low trans-formation, that ſhall be mine: for in euery thing, the pur-pose must weigh with the folly. Follow me Ned.

scene.stagedir: Enter Northumberland, his Ladie, and Harrie Percies Ladie

speech.speaker: North.
speech.line: I prethee louing Wife, and gentle Daughter,
Giue an euen way vnto my rough Affaires:
Put not you on the visage of the Times,
And be like them to Percie, troublesome.

speech.speaker: Wife.
speech.line: I haue giuen ouer, I will ſpeak no more,
Do what you will: your Wisedome, be your guide.

speech.speaker: North.
speech.line: Alas (sweet Wife) my Honor is at pawne,
And but my going, nothing can redeeme it.

speech.speaker: La.
speech.line: Oh yet, for heauens ſake, go not to these Warrs;
The Time was (Father) when you broke your word,
When you were more endeer’d to it, then now,
When your owne Percy, when my heart-deere- Harry,
Threw many a Northward looke, to ſee his Father
Bring vp his Powres: but he did long in vaine.
Who then perswaded you to ſtay at home?
There were two Honors lost; Yours, and your Sonnes.
For Yours, may heauenly glory brighten it:
For His, it ſtucke vpon him, as the Sunne
In the gray vault of Heauen: and by his Light
Did all the Cheualrie of England moue
To do braue Acts. He was (indeed) the Glaſſe
Wherein the Noble-Youth did dreſſe themselues.
He had no Legges, that practic’d not his Gate:
And ſpeaking thicke (which Nature made his blemish)
Became the Accents of the Valiant.
For those that could ſpeake low, and tardily,
Would turne their owne Perfection, to Abuse,
To ſeeme like him. So that in Speech, in Gate,
In Diet, in Affections of delight,
In Militarie Rules, Humors of Blood,
He was the Marke, and Glaſſe, Coppy, and Booke,
That fashion’d others. And him, O wondrous! him,
O Miracle of Men! Him did you leaue
(Second to none) vn-seconded by you,
To looke vpon the hideous God of Warre,
In dis-aduantage, to abide a field,
Where nothing but the ſound of Hotspurs Name
Did ſeeme defensible: ſo you left him.
Neuer, O neuer doe his Ghoſt the wrong,
To hold your Honor more precise and nice
With others, then with him. Let them alone:
The Marshall and the Arch-bishop are ſtrong.
Had my ſweet Harry had but halfe their Numbers,
To day might I (hanging on Hotspurs Necke)
Haue talk’d of Monmouth's Graue.

speech.speaker: North.
speech.line: Beshrew your heart,
(Faire Daughter) you doe draw my Spirits from me,
With new lamenting ancient Ouer-sights.
But I must goe, and meet with Danger there,
Or it will ſeeke me in another place,
And finde me worse prouided.

speech.speaker: Wife.
speech.line: O flye to Scotland,
Till that the Nobles, and the armed Commons,
Haue of their Puiſſance made a little taste.

speech.speaker: Lady.
speech.line: If they get ground, and vantage of the King,
Then ioyne you with them, like a Ribbe of Steele,
To make Strength ſtronger. But, for all our loues,
First let them trye themselues. So did your Sonne,
He was ſo ſuffer’d; ſo came I a Widow:
And neuer ſhall haue length of Life enough,
To raine vpon Remembrance with mine Eyes,
That it may grow, and ſprowt, as high as Heauen,
For Recordation to my Noble Husband.

speech.speaker: North.
speech.line: Come, come, go in with me: ‘tis with my Minde
As with the Tyde, ſwell’d vp vnto his height,
That makes a ſtill-stand, running neyther way.
Faine would I goe to meet the Arch-bishop,
But many thousand Reasons hold me backe.
I will resolue for Scotland: there am I,
Till Time and Vantage craue my company.

speech.speaker: 1.Drawer.
speech.line: What hast thou brought there? Apple-Iohns?
Thou know'st Sir Iohn cannot endure an Apple-Iohn.

speech.speaker: 2.Draw.
speech.line: Thou ſay'st true: the Prince once ſet a Dish of Apple-Iohns before him, and told him there were fiue more Sir Iohns: and, putting off his Hat, ſaid, I will now take my leaue of these ſixe drie, round, old-wither’d Knights. It anger’d him to the heart: but hee hath for-got that.

speech.speaker: 1.Draw.
speech.line: Why then couer, and ſet them downe: and ſee if thou canst finde out Sneakes Noyse; Mistris Teare-sheet would faine haue ſome Musique.

speech.speaker: 2.Draw.
speech.line: Sirrha, heere will be the Prince, and Master Points, anon: and they will put on two of our Ierkins, and Aprons, and Sir Iohn must not know of it: Bardolph hath brought word.

speech.speaker: 1.Draw.
speech.line: Then here will be old Vtis: it will be an ex-cellent ſtratagem.

speech.speaker: 2.Draw
speech.line: Ile ſee if I can finde out Sneake.

speech.speaker: Host.
speech.line: Sweet-heart, me thinkes now you are in an ex-cellent good temperalitie: your Pulsidge beates as ex-traordinarily, as heart would desire; and your Colour (I warrant you) is as red as any Rose: But you haue drunke too much Canaries, and that’s a maruellous ſear-ching Wine; and it perfumes the blood, ere wee can ſay what’s this. How doe you now?

speech.speaker: Dol.
speech.line: Better then I was: Hem.

speech.speaker: Host.
speech.line: Why that was well ſaid: A good heart's worth
Gold. Looke, here comes Sir Iohn.

speech.speaker: Falst.
speech.line: When Arthur first in Court — (emptie the Iordan) and was a worthy King: How now Mistris Dol?

speech.speaker: Host.
speech.line: Sick of a Calme: yea, good-sooth.

speech.speaker: Falst.
speech.line: So is all her Sect: if they be once in a Calme, they are ſick.

speech.speaker: Dol.
speech.line: You muddie Rascall, is that all the comfort you giue me?

speech.speaker: Falst.
speech.line: You make fat Rascalls, Mistris Dol.

speech.speaker: Dol.
speech.line: I make them? Gluttonie and Diseases make them, I make them not.

speech.speaker: Falst.
speech.line: If the Cooke make the Gluttonie, you helpe to make the Diseases (Dol) we catch of you (Dol) we catch of you: Grant that, my poore Vertue, grant that.

speech.speaker: Dol.
speech.line: I marry, our Chaynes, and our Iewels.

speech.speaker: Falst.
speech.line: Your Brooches, Pearles, and Owches: For to ſerue brauely, is to come halting off: you know, to come off the Breach, with his Pike bent brauely, and to Surge-rie brauely; to venture vpon the charg’d-Chambers brauely.

speech.speaker: Host.
speech.line: Why this is the olde fashion: you two neuer meete, but you fall to ſome discord: you are both (in good troth) as Rheumatike as two drie Tostes, you can-not one beare with anothers Confirmities. What the good-yere? One must beare, and that must bee you: you are the weaker Veſſell; as they ſay, the emptier Veſſell.

speech.speaker: Dol.
speech.line: Can a weake emptie Veſſell beare ſuch a huge full Hogs-head? There's a whole Marchants Venture of Burdeux-Stuffe in him: you haue not ſeene a Hulke better ſtufft in the Hold. Come, Ile be friends with thee Iacke: Thou art going to the Warres, and whether I ſhall euer ſee thee againe, or no, there is no body cares.

speech.speaker: Drawer.
speech.line: Sir, Ancient Pistoll is below, and would ſpeake with you.

speech.speaker: Dol.
speech.line: Hang him, ſwaggering Rascall, let him not come hither: it is the foule-mouth’dst Rogue in Eng-land.

speech.speaker: Host.
speech.line: If hee ſwagger, let him not come here: I must liue amongst my Neighbors, Ile no Swaggerers: I am in good name, and fame, with the very best: ſhut the doore, there comes no Swaggerers heere: I haue not liu’d all this while, to haue ſwaggering now: ſhut the doore, I pray you.

speech.speaker: Falst.
speech.line: Do'st thou heare, Hosteſſe?

speech.speaker: Host.
speech.line: 'Pray you pacifie your ſelfe (Sir Iohn) there comes no Swaggerers heere.

speech.speaker: Falst.
speech.line: Do'st thou heare? it is mine Ancient.

speech.speaker: Host.
speech.line: Tilly-fally (Sir Iohn) neuer tell me, your ancient Swaggerer comes not in my doores. I was before Master Tisick the Deputie, the other day: and as hee ſaid to me, it was no longer agœ then Wednesday last: Neighbour Quickly (sayes hee;) Master Dombe, our Minister, was by then: Neighbour Quickly (sayes hee) receiue those that are Ciuill; for (sayth hee) you are in an ill Name: now hee ſaid ſo, I can tell whereupon: for (sayes hee) you are an honeſt Woman, and well thought on; therefore take heede what Guests you receiue: Receiue (sayes hee) no ſwaggering Companions. There comes none heere. You would bleſſe you to heare what hee ſaid. No, Ile no Swaggerers.

speech.speaker: Falst.
speech.line: Hee's no Swaggerer (Hosteſſe:) a tame Cheater, hee: you may ſtroake him as gently, as a Puppie Grey-hound: hee will not ſwagger with a Barbarie Henne, if her feathers turne backe in any ſhew of resistance. Call him vp (Drawer.)

speech.speaker: Host.
speech.line: Cheater, call you him? I will barre no honeſt man my house, nor no Cheater: but I doe not loue ſwag-gering; I am the worse when one ſayes, ſwagger: Feele Masters, how I ſhake: looke you, I warrant you.

speech.speaker: Dol.
speech.line: So you doe, Hosteſſe.

speech.speaker: Host.
speech.line: Doe I? yea, in very truth doe I, if it were an As-pen
Leafe: I cannot abide Swaggerers.

scene.stagedir: Enter Pistol, and Bardolph and his Boy.

speech.speaker: Pist.
speech.line: 'Saue you, Sir Iohn.

speech.speaker: Falst.
speech.line: Welcome Ancient Pistol. Here (Pistol) I charge you with a Cup of Sacke: doe you discharge vpon mine Hosteſſe.

speech.speaker: Pist.
speech.line: I will discharge vpon her (Sir Iohn) with two
Bullets.

speech.speaker: Falst.
speech.line: She is Pistoll-proofe (Sir) you ſhall hardly of-fend her.

speech.speaker: Host.
speech.line: Come, Ile drinke no Proofes, nor no Bullets: I will drinke no more then will doe me good, for no mans pleasure, I.

speech.speaker: Pist.
speech.line: Then to you (Mistris Dorothie) I will charge you.

speech.speaker: Dol.
speech.line: Charge me? I ſcorne you (scuruie Companion) what? you poore, base, rascally, cheating, lacke-Linnen-Mate: away you mouldie Rogue, away; I am meat for your Master.

speech.speaker: Pist.
speech.line: I know you, Mistris Dorothie.

speech.speaker: Dol.
speech.line: Away you Cut-purse Rascall, you filthy Bung, away: By this Wine, Ile thrust my Knife in your mouldie Chappes, if you play the ſawcie Cuttle with me. Away you Bottle-Ale Rascall, you Basket-hilt ſtale Iugler, you. Since when, I pray you, Sir? what, with two Points on your ſhoulder? much.

speech.speaker: Pist.
speech.line: I will murther your Ruffe, for this.

speech.speaker: Host.
speech.line: No, good Captaine Pistol: not heere, ſweete
Captaine.

speech.speaker: Dol.
speech.line: Captaine? thou abhominable damn’d Cheater, art thou not asham’d to be call’d Captaine? If Captaines were of my minde, they would trunchion you out, for ta-king their Names vpon you, before you haue earn’d them. You a Captaine? you ſlaue, for what? for tearing a poore Whores Ruffe in a Bawdy-house? Hee a Captaine? hang him Rogue, hee liues vpon mouldie ſtew’d-Pruines, and dry’de Cakes. A Captaine? These Villaines will make the word Captaine odious: Therefore Captaines had neede looke to it.

speech.speaker: Bard.
speech.line: 'Pray thee goe downe, good Ancient.

speech.speaker: Falst.
speech.line: Hearke thee hither, Mistris Dol.

speech.speaker: Pist.
speech.line: Not I: I tell thee what, Corporall Bardolph, I could teare her: Ile be reueng’d on her.

speech.speaker: Page.
speech.line: 'Pray thee goe downe.

speech.speaker: Pist.
speech.line: Ile ſee her damn’d first: to Pluto's damn’d Lake, to the Infernall Deepe, where Erebus and Tortures vilde also. Hold Hooke and Line, ſay I: Downe: downe Dogges, downe Fates: haue wee not Hiren here?

speech.speaker: Host.
speech.line: Good Captaine Peesel be quiet, it is very late:
I beseeke you now, aggrauate your Choler.

speech.speaker: Pist.
speech.line: These be good Humors indeede. Shall Pack-Horses, and hollow-pamper’d Iades of Asia, which can-not goe but thirtie miles a day, compare with Caesar, and with Caniballs, and Troian Greekes? nay, rather damne them with King Cerberus, and let the Welkin roare: ſhall wee fall foule for Toyes?

speech.speaker: Host.
speech.line: By my troth Captaine, these are very bitter words.

speech.speaker: Bard.
speech.line: Be gone, good Ancient: this will grow to a
Brawle anon.

speech.speaker: Pist.
speech.line: Die men, like Dogges; giue Crownes like Pinnes:
Haue we not Hiren here?

speech.speaker: Host.
speech.line: On my word (Captaine) there's none ſuch here.
What the good-yere, doe you thinke I would denye her?
I pray be quiet.

speech.speaker: Pist.
speech.line: Then feed, and be fat (my faire Calipolis.) Come, giue me ſome Sack, Si fortune me tormente, ſperato me con-tente. Feare wee broad-sides? No, let the Fiend giue fire: Giue me ſome Sack: and Sweet-heart lye thou there: Come wee to full Points here, and are et cetera's no-thing? _

speech.speaker: Fal.
speech.line: Pistol, I would be quiet.

speech.speaker: Pist.
speech.line: Sweet Knight, I kiſſe thy Neaffe: what? wee haue ſeene the ſeuen Starres.

speech.speaker: Dol.
speech.line: Thrust him downe ſtayres, I cannot endure ſuch a Fustian Rascall.

speech.speaker: Pist.
speech.line: Thrust him downe ſtayres? know we not Gallo-way
Nagges?

speech.speaker: Fal.
speech.line: Quoit him downe (Bardolph) like a ſhoue-groat ſhilling: nay, if hee doe nothing but ſpeake nothing, hee ſhall be nothing here.

speech.speaker: Bard.
speech.line: Come, get you downe ſtayres.

speech.speaker: Pist.
speech.line: What? ſhall wee haue Incision? ſhall wee em-brew? then Death rocke me asleepe, abridge my dolefull dayes: why then let grieuous, gastly, gaping Wounds, vntwin’d the Sisters three: Come Atropos, I ſay.

speech.speaker: Host.
speech.line: Here's good ſtuffe toward.

speech.speaker: Fal.
speech.line: Giue me my Rapier, Boy.

speech.speaker: Dol.
speech.line: I prethee Iack, I prethee doe not draw.

speech.speaker: Fal.
speech.line: Get you downe ſtayres.

speech.speaker: Host.
speech.line: Here's a goodly tumult: Ile forsweare keeping house, before Ile be in these tirrits, and frights. So: Mur-ther I warrant now. Alas, alas, put vp your naked Wea-pons, put vp your naked Weapons.

speech.speaker: Dol.
speech.line: I prethee Iack be quiet, the Rascall is gone: ah, you whorson little valiant Villaine, you.

speech.speaker: Host.
speech.line: Are you not hurt i'th’ Groyne? me thought hee made a ſhrewd Thrust at your Belly.

speech.speaker: Fal.
speech.line: Haue you turn’d him out of doores?

speech.speaker: Bard.
speech.line: Yes Sir: the Rascall's drunke: you haue hurt him (Sir) in the ſhoulder.

speech.speaker: Fal.
speech.line: A Rascall to braue me.

speech.speaker: Dol.
speech.line: Ah, you ſweet little Rogue, you: alas, poore Ape, how thou ſweat'st? Come, let me wipe thy Face: Come on, you whorson Chops: Ah Rogue, I loue thee: Thou art as valorous as Hector of Troy, worth fiue of Agamem-non, and tenne times better then the nine Worthies: ah Villaine.

speech.speaker: Fal.
speech.line: A rascally Slaue, I will toſſe the Rogue in a Blan-ket.

speech.speaker: Dol.
speech.line: Doe, if thou dar'st for thy heart: if thou doo'st,
Ile canuas thee betweene a paire of Sheetes.

speech.speaker: Page.
speech.line: The Musique is come, Sir.

speech.speaker: Fal.
speech.line: Let them play: play Sirs. Sit on my Knee, Dol.
A Rascall, bragging Slaue: the Rogue fled from me like
Quick-siluer.

speech.speaker: Dol.
speech.line: And thou followd'st him like a Church: thou whorson little tydie Bartholmew Bore-pigge, when wilt thou leaue fighting on dayes, and foyning on nights, and begin to patch vp thine old Body for Heauen?

scene.stagedir: Enter the Prince and Poines disguis’d.

speech.speaker: Fal.
speech.line: Peace (good Dol) doe not ſpeake like a Deaths-head: doe not bid me remember mine end.

speech.speaker: Dol.
speech.line: Sirrha, what humor is the Prince of?

speech.speaker: Fal.
speech.line: A good ſhallow young fellow: hee would haue made a good Pantler, hee would haue chipp’d Bread well.

speech.speaker: Dol.
speech.line: They ſay Poines hath a good Wit.

speech.speaker: Fal.
speech.line: Hee a good Wit? hang him Baboone, his Wit is as thicke as Tewksburie Mustard: there is no more con-ceit in him, then is in a Mallet.

speech.speaker: Dol.
speech.line: Why doth the Prince loue him ſo then?

speech.speaker: Fal.
speech.line: Because their Legges are both of a bigneſſe: and hee playes at Quoits well, and eates Conger and Fennell, and drinkes off Candles ends for Flap-dragons, and rides the wilde-Mare with the Boyes, and iumpes vpon Ioyn’d-stooles, and ſweares with a good grace, and weares his Boot very ſmooth, like vnto the Signe of the Legge; and breedes no bate with telling of discreete ſtories: and ſuch other Gamboll Faculties hee hath, that ſhew a weake Minde, and an able Body, for the which the Prince admits him; for the Prince himselfe is ſuch another: the weight of an hayre will turne the Scales betweene their Haber-de-pois.

speech.speaker: Prince.
speech.line: Would not this Naue of a Wheele haue his
Eares cut off?

speech.speaker: Poin.
speech.line: Let vs beat him before his Whore.

speech.speaker: Prince.
speech.line: Looke, if the wither’d Elder hath not his Poll claw’d like a Parrot.

speech.speaker: Poin.
speech.line: Is it not ſtrange, that Desire ſhould ſo many yeeres out-liue performance?

speech.speaker: Fal.
speech.line: Kiſſe me Dol.

speech.speaker: Prince.
speech.line: Saturne and Venus this yeere in Coniunction?
What ſayes the Almanack to that?

speech.speaker: Poin.
speech.line: And looke whether the fierie Trigon, his Man, be not lisping to his Masters old Tables, his Note-Booke, his Councell-keeper?

speech.speaker: Fal.
speech.line: Thou do'st giue me flatt'ring Buſſes.

speech.speaker: Dol.
speech.line: Nay truely, I kiſſe thee with a mo’t constant heart.

speech.speaker: Fal.
speech.line: I am olde, I am olde.

speech.speaker: Dol.
speech.line: I loue thee better, then I loue ere a ſcuruie young
Boy of them all.

speech.speaker: Fal.
speech.line: What Stuffe wilt thou haue a Kirtle of? I ſhall receiue Money on Thursday: thou ſhalt haue a Cappe to morrow. A merrie Song, come: it growes late, wee will to Bed. Thou wilt forget me, when I am gone.

speech.speaker: Dol.
speech.line: Thou wilt ſet me a weeping, if thou ſay'st ſo: proue that euer I dreſſe my ſelfe handsome, till thy re-turne: well, hearken the end.

speech.speaker: Fal.
speech.line: Some Sack, Francis.
Prin. Poin.
Anon, anon, Sir.

speech.speaker: Fal.
speech.line: Ha? a Bastard Sonne of the Kings? And art not thou Poines, his Brother?

speech.speaker: Prince.
speech.line: Why thou Globe of ſinfull Continents, what a life do'st thou lead?

speech.speaker: Fal.
speech.line: A better then thou: I am a Gentleman, thou art a Drawer.

speech.speaker: Prince.
speech.line: Very true, Sir: and I come to draw you out by the Eares.

speech.speaker: Host.
speech.line: Oh, the Lord preserue thy good Grace: Wel-come to London. Now Heauen bleſſe that ſweete Face of thine: what, are you come from Wales?

speech.speaker: Fal.
speech.line: Thou whorson mad Compound of Maiestie: by this light Flesh, and corrupt Blood, thou art welcome.

speech.speaker: Dol.
speech.line: How? you fat Foole, I ſcorne you.

speech.speaker: Poin.
speech.line: My Lord, hee will driue you out of your re-uenge, and turne all to a merryment, if you take not the heat.

speech.speaker: Prince.
speech.line: You whorson Candle-myne you, how vildly did you ſpeake of me euen now, before this honeſt, ver-tuous, ciuill Gentlewoman?

speech.speaker: Host.
speech.line: 'Bleſſing on your good heart, and ſo ſhee is by my troth.

speech.speaker: Fal.
speech.line: Didst thou heare me?

speech.speaker: Prince.
speech.line: Yes: and you knew me, as you did when you ranne away by Gads-hill: you knew I was at your back, and ſpoke it on purpose, to trie my patience.

speech.speaker: Fal.
speech.line: No, no, no: not ſo: I did not thinke, thou wast within hearing.

speech.speaker: Prince.
speech.line: I ſhall driue you then to confeſſe the wilfull abuse, and then I know how to handle you.

speech.speaker: Fal.
speech.line: No abuse (Hall) on mine Honor, no abuse.

speech.speaker: Prince.
speech.line: Not to disprayse me? and call me Pantler, and
Bread-chopper, and I know not what?

speech.speaker: Fal.
speech.line: No abuse (Hal.)

speech.speaker: Poin.
speech.line: No abuse?

speech.speaker: Fal.
speech.line: No abuse (Ned) in the World: honeſt Ned none. I disprays’d him before the Wicked, that the Wicked might not fall in loue with him: In which doing, I haue done the part of a carefull Friend, and a true Subiect, and thy Father is to giue me thankes for it. No abuse (Hal:) none (Ned) none; no Boyes, none.

speech.speaker: Prince.
speech.line: See now whether pure Feare, and entire Cow-ardise, doth not make thee wrong this vertuous Gentle-woman, to close with vs? Is ſhee of the Wicked? Is thine Hosteſſe heere, of the Wicked? Or is the Boy of the Wicked? Or honeſt Bardolph (whose Zeale burnes in his Nose) of the Wicked?

speech.speaker: Poin.
speech.line: Answere thou dead Elme, answere.

speech.speaker: Fal.
speech.line: The Fiend hath prickt downe Bardolph irrecoue-rable, and his Face is Lucifers Priuy-Kitchin, where hee doth nothing but rost Mault-Wormes: for the Boy, there is a good Angell about him, but the Deuill out-bids him too.

speech.speaker: Prince.
speech.line: For the Women?

speech.speaker: Fal.
speech.line: For one of them, ſhee is in Hell alreadie, and burnes poore Soules: for the other, I owe her Mo-ney; and whether ſhee bee damn’d for that, I know not.

speech.speaker: Host.
speech.line: No, I warrant you.

speech.speaker: Fal.
speech.line: No, I thinke thou art not: I thinke thou art quit for that. Marry, there is another Indictment vpon thee, for ſuffering flesh to bee eaten in thy house, contrary to the Law, for the which I thinke thou wilt howle.

speech.speaker: Host.
speech.line: All Victuallers doe ſo: What is a Ioynt of
Mutton, or two, in a whole Lent?

speech.speaker: Prince.
speech.line: You, Gentlewoman.

speech.speaker: Dol.
speech.line: What ſayes your Grace?

speech.speaker: Falst.
speech.line: His Grace ſayes that, which his flesh rebells against.

speech.speaker: Host.
speech.line: Who knocks ſo lowd at doore? Looke to the doore there, Francis?

speech.speaker: Prince.
speech.line: Peto, how now? what newes?

speech.speaker: Peto.
speech.line: The King, your Father, is at Westminster,
And there are twentie weake and wearied Postes,
Come from the North: and as I came along,
I met, and ouer-tooke a dozen Captaines,
Bare-headed, ſweating, knocking at the Tauernes,
And asking euery one for Sir Iohn Falstaffe.

speech.speaker: Prince.
speech.line: By Heauen (Poines) I feele me much to blame,
So idly to prophane the precious time,
When Tempest of Commotion, like the South,
Borne with black Vapour, doth begin to melt,
And drop vpon our bare vnarmed heads.
Giue me my Sword, and Cloake:
Falstaffe, good night.

speech.speaker: Falst.
speech.line: Now comes in the ſweetest Morsell of the night, and wee must hence, and leaue it vnpickt. More knocking at the doore? How now? what’s the mat-ter? _

speech.speaker: Bard.
speech.line: You must away to Court, Sir, presently,
A dozen Captaines ſtay at doore for you.

speech.speaker: Falst.
speech.line: Pay the Musitians, Sirrha: farewell Hosteſſe, farewell Dol. You ſee (my good Wenches) how men of Merit are ſought after: the vndeseruer may ſleepe, when the man of Action is call’d on. Farewell good Wenches: if I be not ſent away poste, I will ſee you againe, ere I goe.

speech.speaker: Dol.
speech.line: I cannot ſpeake: if my heart bee not readie to burst— Well (sweete Iacke) haue a care of thy ſelfe.

speech.speaker: Falst
speech.line: Farewell, farewell.

speech.speaker: Host.
speech.line: Well, fare thee well: I haue knowne thee these twentie nine yeeres, come Pescod-time: but an honester, and truer-hearted man— Well, fare thee well.

speech.speaker: Bard.
speech.line: Mistris Teare-sheet.

speech.speaker: Host.
speech.line: What's the matter?

speech.speaker: Bard.
speech.line: Bid Mistris Teare-sheet come to my Master.

speech.speaker: Host.
speech.line: Oh runne Dol, runne: runne, good Dol.

scene.stagedir: Enter the King, with a Page.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: Goe, call the Earles of Surrey, and of Warwick:
But ere they come, bid them ore-reade these Letters,
And well consider of them: make good ſpeed. Exit.
How many thousand of my poorest Subiects
Are at this howre asleepe? O Sleepe, O gentle Sleepe,
Natures ſoft Nurse, how haue I frighted thee,
That thou no more wilt weigh my eye-lids downe,
And ſteepe my Sences in Forgetfulneſſe?
Why rather (Sleepe) lyest thou in ſmoakie Cribs,
Vpon vneasie Pallads ſtretching thee,
And huisht with buſſing Night, flyes to thy ſlumber,
Then in the perfum’d Chambers of the Great?
Vnder the Canopies of costly State,
And lull’d with ſounds of ſweetest Melodie?
O thou dull God, why lyest thou with the vilde,
In loathsome Beds, and leau'st the Kingly Couch,
A Watch-case, or a common Larum-Bell?
Wilt thou, vpon the high and giddie Mast,
Seale vp the Ship-boyes Eyes, and rock his Braines,
In Cradle of the rude imperious Surge,
And in the visitation of the Windes,
Who take the Ruffian Billowes by the top,
Curling their monstrous heads, and hanging them
With deaff'ning Clamors in the ſlipp'ry Clouds,
That with the hurley, Death it ſelfe awakes?
Canst thou (O partiall Sleepe) giue thy Repose
To the wet Sea-Boy, in an houre ſo rude:
And in the calmest, and mo’t ſtillest Night,
With all appliances, and meanes to boote,
Deny it to a King? Then happy Lowe, lye downe,
Vneasie lyes the Head, that weares a Crowne.

speech.speaker: War.
speech.line: Many good-morrowes to your Maiestie.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: Is it good-morrow, Lords?

speech.speaker: War.
speech.line: ‘Tis One a Clock, and past.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: Why then good-morrow to you all (my Lords:)
Haue you read o’re the Letters that I ſent you?

speech.speaker: War.
speech.line: We haue (my Liege.)

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: Then you perceiue the Body of our Kingdome,
How foule it is: what ranke Diseases grow,
And with what danger, neere the Heart of it?

speech.speaker: War.
speech.line: It is but as a Body, yet distemper’d,
Which to his former ſtrength may be restor’d,
With good aduice, and little Medicine:
My Lord Northumberland will ſoone be cool’d.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: Oh Heauen, that one might read the Book of Fate,
And ſee the reuolution of the Times
Make Mountaines leuell, and the Continent
(Wearie of ſolide firmeneſſe) melt it ſelfe
Into the Sea: and other Times, to ſee
The beachie Girdle of the Ocean
Too wide for Neptunes hippes; how Chances mocks
And Changes fill the Cuppe of Alteration
With diuers Liquors. ‘Tis not tenne yeeres gone,
Since Richard, and Northumberland, great friends,
Did feast together; and in two yeeres after,
Were they at Warres. It is but eight yeeres ſince,
This Percie was the man, neerest my Soule,
Who, like a Brother, toyl’d in my Affaires,
And layd his Loue and Life vnder my foot:
Yea, for my ſake, euen to the eyes of Richard
Gaue him defiance. But which of you was by
(You Cousin Neuil, as I may remember)
When Richard, with his Eye, brim-full of Teares,
(Then check’d, and rated by Northumberland)
Did ſpeake these words (now prou’d a Prophecie:)
Northumberland, thou Ladder, by the which
My Cousin Bullingbrooke ascends my Throne:
(Though then, Heauen knowes, I had no ſuch intent,
But that neceſſitie ſo bow’d the State,
That I and Greatneſſe were compell’d to kiſſe:)
The Time ſhall come (thus did hee follow it)
The Time will come, that foule Sinne gathering head,
Shall breake into Corruption: ſo went on,
Fore-telling this ſame Times Condition,
And the diuision of our Amitie.

speech.speaker: War.
speech.line: There is a Historie in all mens Liues,
Figuring the nature of the Times deceas’d:
The which obseru’d, a man may prophecie
With a neere ayme, of the maine chance of things,
As yet not come to Life, which in their Seedes
And weake beginnings lye entreasured:
Such things become the Hatch and Brood of Time;
And by the neceſſarie forme of this,
King Richard might create a perfect gueſſe,
That great Northumberland, then false to him,
Would of that Seed, grow to a greater falseneſſe,
Which ſhould not finde a ground to roote vpon,
Vnleſſe on you.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: Are these things then Neceſſities?
Then let vs meete them like Neceſſities;
And that ſame word, euen now cryes out on vs:
They ſay, the Bishop and Northumberland
Are fiftie thousand ſtrong.

speech.speaker: War.
speech.line: It cannot be (my Lord:)
Rumor doth double, like the Voice, and Eccho,
The numbers of the feared. Please it your Grace
To goe to bed, vpon my Life (my Lord)
The Pow'rs that you alreadie haue ſent forth,
Shall bring this Prize in very easily.
To comfort you the more, I haue receiu’d
A certaine instance, that Glendour is dead.
