speech.line: Giue me pardon, Sir. If ſir, you come with news from the Court, I take it, there is but two wayes, either to vtter them, or to conceale them. I am Sir, vnder the King, in ſome Authority.

speech.speaker: Pist.
speech.line: Vnder which King?
Bezonian, ſpeake, or dye.

speech.speaker: Shal.
speech.line: Vnder King Harry.

speech.speaker: Pist.
speech.line: Harry the Fourth? or Fift?

speech.speaker: Shal.
speech.line: Harry the Fourth.

speech.speaker: Pist.
speech.line: A footra for thine Office.
Sir Iohn, thy tender Lamb-kinne, now is King,
Harry the Fift's the man, I ſpeake the truth.
When Pistoll lyes, do this, and figge-me, like
The bragging Spaniard.

speech.speaker: Fal.
speech.line: What, is the old King dead?

speech.speaker: Pist.
speech.line: As naile in doore.
The things I ſpeake, are iust.

speech.speaker: Fal.
speech.line: Away Bardolfe, Sadle my Horse,
Master Robert Shallow, choose what Office thou wilt
In the Land, ‘tis thine. Pistol, I will double charge thee
With Dignities.

speech.speaker: Bard.
speech.line: O ioyfull day:
I would not take a Knighthood for my Fortune.

speech.speaker: Pist.
speech.line: What? I do bring good newes.

speech.speaker: Fal.
speech.line: Carrie Master Silence to bed: Master Shallow, my Lord Shallow, be what thou wilt, I am Fortunes Steward. Get on thy Boots, wee'l ride all night. Oh ſweet Pistoll: Away Bardolfe: Come Pistoll, vtter more to mee: and withall deuise ſomething to do thy ſelfe good. Boote, boote Master Shallow, I know the young King is ſick for mee. Let vs take any mans Horſſes: The Lawes of Eng-land are at my command'ment. Happie are they, which haue beene my Friendes: and wœ vnto my Lord Chiefe Iustice.

speech.speaker: Pist.
speech.line: Let Vultures vil’de ſeize on his Lungs also:
Where is the life that late I led, ſay they?
Why heere it is, welcome those pleasant dayes.

scene.stagedir: Enter Hosteſſe Quickly, Dol Teare-sheete, and Beadles

speech.speaker: Hosteſſe.
speech.line: No, thou arrant knaue: I would I might dy, that I might haue thee hang’d: Thou hast drawne my ſhoulder out of ioynt.

speech.speaker: Off.
speech.line: The Constables haue deliuer’d her ouer to mee: and ſhee ſhall haue Whipping cheere enough, I warrant her. There hath beene a man or two (lately) kill’d about her.

speech.speaker: Dol.
speech.line: Nut-hooke, nut-hooke, you Lye: Come on, Ile tell thee what, thou damn’d Tripe-visag’d Rascall, if the Childe I now go with, do miscarrie, thou had'st better thou had'st ſtrooke thy Mother, thou Paper-fac’d Vil-laine. _

speech.speaker: Host.
speech.line: O that Sir Iohn were come, hee would make this a bloody day to ſome body. But I would the Fruite of her Wombe might miscarry.

speech.speaker: Officer.
speech.line: If it do, you ſhall haue a dozen of Cushions againe, you haue but eleuen now. Come, I charge you both go with me: for the man is dead, that you and Pi-stoll beate among you.

speech.speaker: Dol.
speech.line: Ile tell thee what, thou thin man in a Censor; I will haue you as ſoundly ſwindg’d for this, you blew-Bottel’d Rogue: you filthy famish’d Correctioner, if you be not ſwing’d, Ile forsweare halfe Kirtles.

speech.speaker: Off.
speech.line: Come, come, you ſhee-Knight-arrant, come.

speech.speaker: Host.
speech.line: O, that right ſhould thus o’recome might. Wel of ſufferance, comes ease.

speech.speaker: Dol.
speech.line: Come you Rogue, come:
Bring me to a Iustice.

speech.speaker: Host.
speech.line: Yes, come you ſtaru’d Blood-hound.

speech.speaker: Dol.
speech.line: Goodman death, goodman Bones.

speech.speaker: Host.
speech.line: Thou Anatomy, thou.

speech.speaker: Dol.
speech.line: Come you thinne Thing:
Come you Rascall.

speech.speaker: Off
speech.line: Very well.

speech.speaker: 1.Groo.
speech.line: More Rushes, more Rushes.

speech.speaker: 2.Groo.
speech.line: The Trumpets haue ſounded twice.

speech.speaker: 1.Groo.
speech.line: It will be two of the Clocke, ere they come from the Coronation.

scene.stagedir: Enter Falstaffe, Shallow, Pistoll, Bardolfe, and Page.

speech.speaker: Falstaffe.
speech.line: Stand heere by me, M[aster]. Robert Shallow, I will make the King do you Grace. I will leere vpon him, as he comes by: and do but marke the countenance that hee will giue me.

speech.speaker: Pistol.
speech.line: Bleſſe thy Lungs, good Knight.

speech.speaker: Falst.
speech.line: Come heere Pistol, ſtand behind me. O if I had had time to haue made new Liueries, I would haue be-stowed the thousand pound I borrowed of you. But it is no matter, this poore ſhew doth better: this doth inferre the zeale I had to ſee him.

speech.speaker: Shal.
speech.line: It doth ſo.

speech.speaker: Falst.
speech.line: It ſhewes my earnestneſſe in affection.

speech.speaker: Pist.
speech.line: It doth ſo.

speech.speaker: Fal.
speech.line: My deuotion.

speech.speaker: Pist.
speech.line: It doth, it doth, it doth.

speech.speaker: Fal.
speech.line: As it were, to ride day and night,
And not to deliberate, not to remember,
Not to haue patience to ſhift me.

speech.speaker: Shal.
speech.line: It is mo’t certaine.

speech.speaker: Fal.
speech.line: But to ſtand ſtained with Trauaile, and ſweating with desire to ſee him, thinking of nothing else, putting all affayres in obliuion, as if there were nothing els to bee done, but to ſee him.

speech.speaker: Pist.
speech.line: ‘Tis ſemper idem: for obsque hoc nihil est. ‘Tis all in euery part.

speech.speaker: Shal.
speech.line: ‘Tis ſo indeed.

speech.speaker: Pist.
speech.line: My Knight, I will enflame thy Noble Liuer, and make thee rage. Thy Dol, and Helen of thy noble thoghts is in base Durance, and contagious prison: Hall’d thi-ther by mo’t Mechanicall and durty hand. Rowze vppe Reuenge from Ebon den, with fell Alecto's Snake, for Dol is in. Pistol, ſpeakes nought but troth.

speech.speaker: Fal.
speech.line: I will deliuer her.

speech.speaker: Pistol.
speech.line: There roar’d the Sea: and Trumpet Clangour ſounds.

scene.stagedir: The Trumpets ſound. Enter King Henrie the Fift, Brothers, Lord Chiefe Iustice

speech.speaker: Falst.
speech.line: Saue thy Grace, King Hall, my Royall Hall.

speech.speaker: Pist.
speech.line: The heauens thee guard, and keepe, mo’t royall
Impe of Fame.

speech.speaker: Fal.
speech.line: 'Saue thee my ſweet Boy.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: My Lord Chiefe Iustice, ſpeake to that vaine man.

speech.speaker: Ch.Iust.
speech.line: Haue you your wits?
Know you what ‘tis you ſpeake?

speech.speaker: Falst.
speech.line: My King, my Ioue; I ſpeake to thee, my heart.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: I know thee not, old man: Fall to thy Prayers:
How ill white haires become a Foole, and Iester?
I haue long dream’d of ſuch a kinde of man,
So ſurfeit-swell’d, ſo old, and ſo prophane:
But being awake, I do despise my dreame.
Make leſſe thy body (hence) and more thy Grace,
Leaue gourmandizing; Know the Graue doth gape
For thee, thrice wider then for other men.
Reply not to me, with a Foole-borne Iest,
Presume not, that I am the thing I was,
For heauen doth know (so ſhall the world perceiue)
That I haue turn’d away my former Selfe,
So will I those that kept me Companie.
When thou dost heare I am, as I haue bin,
Approach me, and thou ſhalt be as thou was't
The Tutor and the Feeder of my Riots:
Till then, I banish thee, on paine of death,
As I haue done the rest of my Misleaders,
Not to come neere our Person, by ten mile.
For competence of life, I will allow you,
That lacke of meanes enforce you not to euill:
And as we heare you do reforme your ſelues,
We will according to your ſtrength, and qualities,
Giue you aduancement. Be it your charge (my Lord)
To ſee perform’d the tenure of our word. Set on.

speech.speaker: Fal.
speech.line: Master Shallow, I owe you a thousand pound.

speech.speaker: Shal.
speech.line: I marry Sir Iohn, which I beseech you to let me haue home with me.

speech.speaker: Fal.
speech.line: That can hardly be, M[aster]. Shallow, do not you grieue at this: I ſhall be ſent for in priuate to him: Looke you, he must ſeeme thus to the world: feare not your aduance-ment: I will be the man yet, that ſhall make you great.

speech.speaker: Shal.
speech.line: I cannot well perceiue how, vnleſſe you ſhould giue me your Doublet, and ſtuffe me out with Straw. I beseech you, good Sir Iohn, let mee haue fiue hundred of my thousand.

speech.speaker: Fal.
speech.line: Sir, I will be as good as my word. This that you heard, was but a colour.

speech.speaker: Shall.
speech.line: A colour I feare, that you will dye in, Sir Iohn.

speech.speaker: Fal.
speech.line: Feare no colours, go with me to dinner:
Come Lieutenant Pistol, come Bardolfe,
I ſhall be ſent for ſoone at night.

speech.speaker: Ch.Iust.
speech.line: Go carry Sir Iohn Falstaffe to the Fleete,
Take all his Company along with him.

speech.speaker: Fal.
speech.line: My Lord, my Lord.

speech.speaker: Ch.Iust.
speech.line: I cannot now ſpeake, I will heare you ſoone:
Take them away.

speech.speaker: Pist.
speech.line: Si fortuna me tormento, ſpera me contento.

scene.stagedir: Exit. Manent Lancaster and Chiefe Iustice.

speech.speaker: Iohn.
speech.line: I like this faire proceeding of the Kings:
He hath intent his wonted Followers
Shall all be very well prouided for:
But all are banisht, till their conuersations
Appeare more wise, and modest to the world.

speech.speaker: Ch.Iust.
speech.line: And ſo they are.

speech.speaker: Iohn.
speech.line: The King hath call’d his Parliament,
My Lord.

speech.speaker: Ch.Iust.
speech.line: He hath.

speech.speaker: Iohn.
speech.line: I will lay oddes, that ere this yeere expire,
We beare our Ciuill Swords, and Natiue fire
As farre as France. I heare a Bird ſo ſing,
Whose Musicke (to my thinking) pleas’d the King.
Come, will you hence?

speech.speaker: EPILOGVE.
speech.line: First, my Feare: then, my Curtsie: last, my Speech. My Feare, is your Displeasure: My Curtsie, my Dutie: And my ſpeech, to Begge your Pardons. If you looke for a good ſpeech now, you vndœ me: For what I haue to ſay, is of mine owne making: and what (indeed) I ſhould ſay, will (I doubt) prooue mine owne marring. But to the Purpose, and ſo to the Venture. Be it knowne to you (as it is very well) I was lately heere in the end of a displeasing Play, to pray your Patience for it, and to promise you a Better: I did meane (indeede) to pay you with this, which if (like an ill Venture) it come vnluckily home, I breake; and you, my gen= tle Creditors lose. Heere I promist you I would be, and heere I commit my Bodie to your Mercies: Bate me ſome, and I will pay you ſome, and (as mo’t Debtors do) promise you infinitely. If my Tongue cannot entreate you to acquit me: will you command me to vse my Legges? And yet that were but light payment, to Dance out of your debt: But a good Conscience, will make any poſſible ſatisfaction, and ſo will I. All these Gen= tlewomen heere, haue forgiuen me, if the Gentlemen will not, then the Gentlemen do not agree with the Gentlewomen, which was neuer ſeene before, in ſuch an As ſembly. One word more, I beseech you: if you be not too much cloid with Fat Meate, our humble Author will continue the Story (with Sir Iohn in it) and make you merry, with faire Katherine of France: where (for any thing I know) Fal- ſtaffe ſhall dye of a ſweat, vnleſſe already he be kill’d with your hard Opinions: For Old-Castle dyed a Martyr, and this is not the man. My Tongue is wearie, when my Legs are too, I will bid you good night; and ſo kneele downe before you; But (indeed) to pray for the Queene. THE ACTORS NAMES. Rumour the Presentor. King Henry the Fourth. Prince Henry, afterwards Crowned King Henrie the Fift. Prince Iohn of Lancaster. Humphrey of Gloucester. Thomas of Clarence. Sonnes to Henry the Fourth, & brethren to Henry 5. Northumberland. The Arch Byshop of Yorke. Mowbray. Hastings. Lord Bardolfe. Trauers. Morton. Coleuile. Opposites against King Henrie the Fourth. Warwicke. Westmerland. Surrey. Gowre. Harecourt. Lord Chiefe Iustice. Of the Kings Partie. Shallow. Silence. Both Country Iustices. Dauie, Seruant to Shallow. Phang, and Snare, 2. Serieants Mouldie. Shadow. Wart. Feeble. Bullcalfe. Country Soldiers Pointz. Falstaffe. Bardolphe. Pistoll. Peto. Page. Irregular Humorists. Drawers Beadles. Groomes Northumberlands Wife. Percies Widdow. Hosteſſe Quickly. Doll Teare-sheete. Epilogue. The Second Part of Henry the Fourth, Containing his Death: and the Coronation of King Henry the Fift
